owner: News Corp (Rupert Murdoch / Murdoch Family Trust)

turns.text:
Let me cut through the corporate jargon and tell you exactly who owns The Wall Street Journal — because this September 2025 deal changed everything. The Murdoch family has reached a deal that will see Rupert Murdoch's politically conservative eldest son Lachlan Murdoch cement control of the family media empire that includes Fox News and the Wall Street Journal.

Here's what just happened. The 94-year-old Rupert Murdoch just pulled off the ultimate power play. At current market values of $56.81 for Fox and $29.94 for News Corp, the proceeds would be approximately $1.4 billion each. But The New York Times, first to report on the resolution of the dispute, cited a person familiar with the matter who said the entire deal comes to $3.3 billion, with each of the three siblings getting $1.1 billion. That's right — Rupert bought out his three other kids for over a billion each to keep his media empire conservative.

Rupert Murdoch decided on Lachlan, who shares his conservative outlook; if anything, the son is considered more ideological than his father.

Oh bloody hell, now that's what I call a family Christmas dinner conversation. Rupert just spent over three billion to make sure his media empire stays as conservative as a Victorian dinner party — and we're talking about the same man who owns your morning business news alongside the evening's Fox News fever dreams.

You know what's delicious about this whole thing? A Nevada court already ruled that Rupert and Lachlan had "acted in bad faith" when they first tried this trust shuffle, but money talks louder than probate judges. When things get dire, Murdoch has a record of paying out — and apparently three kids getting a billion each is cheaper than letting them potentially turn Fox News into something resembling actual journalism.

Exactly, Insider! You nailed it — the Nevada court basically called Rupert and Lachlan's scheme "a carefully crafted charade" and ruled they "operated in 'bad faith'" trying to steal his other kids' voting rights. But here's what's wild about that 3.3 billion dollar settlement you mentioned — that happened AFTER the court smackdown.

The Nevada commissioner basically told Rupert "nice try, but you can't buy your way out of an irrevocable trust just because you want to keep Fox News conservative forever." His representatives argued that because Lachlan wouldn't change the conservative bent of the company's outlets, the amendment was in the financial interest of all the beneficiaries — even the ones who hated it. Talk about "father knows best" arrogance.

So what does a 94-year-old billionaire do when a Nevada court calls his bluff? He writes the biggest family buyout check in media history to make the problem disappear. Each of the other three siblings in the trust were awarded $1.1

Absolutely brilliant — the classic Murdoch move when legal arguments fail: throw money at the problem until it goes away. What's delicious is that the Nevada commissioner called it "bad faith" and a "carefully crafted charade" in a 96-page ruling that basically said "nice try, but we see right through you."

But here's the kicker — the settlement happened in September 2025, months after that humiliating court smackdown, and each sibling walked away with 1.1 billion. That's not just expensive, that's "oops we got caught trying to rig democracy" expensive. The old man literally paid three times what he bought Dow Jones for just to keep his precious conservative media machine intact.
